awd_titl_txt: ATD: Global Terrorism Threat Detection by Nonstationary, Spatio-Temporal Hawkes Process Models
awd_abstract_narration:
The threat of terrorism is a pressing global security concern, with thousands of terror attacks producing tens of thousands of deaths annually. Analyzing patterns of prior terror events is one of the primary ways researchers can learn about terrorism and its determinants, thereby enabling governments to craft more effective counter-terrorism policy in the future. Yet, most statistical models used by researchers are ill-suited to capture the complex dynamics of global terrorism. For example, it is known that acts of terrorism often produce subsequent acts of terror. However, current understanding of the evolution of terror campaigns remains limited and constrained by methods which either assume independence across events or lack sufficiently flexible models of dependence. In this project, the PIs plan to generalize these statistical approaches to make them better suited for the analysis of global terrorism, and to help identify more complex interactions within and across terror campaigns.  The results of this project will ultimately benefit policy makers and aid government efforts to curb such violence. The PIs will author popular summaries of the project results for general audiences, and integrate the proposed research with education through training graduate students and developing courses.    

This multidisciplinary project aims to develop spatio-temporal Hawkes process models on a global scale with flexible nonstationary spatio-temporal intensity functions. Current Hawkes process models found in the literature are often univariate, defined only on the planar domain, and do not permit spatio-temporal interactions. The PIs will develop Hawkes process models defined on the surface of a sphere with a flexible spatio-temporal structure in the triggering function. Specific developments will include spatio-temporal nonstationarity, non-separability, and asymmetry. Multivariate extensions of the proposed models will be pursued to simultaneously model varied attack types or attacks by multiple terrorist groups. Statistical inference with numerical computation of the likelihood for massive global data, and procedures for hypothesis tests of spatio-temporal structures in point pattern data will be studied. Proposed methods will be applied to the analysis of individual terrorist groups in single countries, as well as global terrorism patterns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved the development of statistical models and methods to
better analyze patterns of terrorism. Using the location and timing information
provided in incident-level terrorism data, we were able to treat terror attacks
as spatial and spatio-temporal point patterns. Existing models of spatial and
spatio-temporal point patterns were not sufficiently flexible to capture the complex dynamics which characterized the patterns observed in these data. By
generalizing these models to better suit these terror data, we were able to reveal
patterns of behavior that more restrictive models are, by construction, unable
to produce. As a result, we observed that our model was superior to existing
alternatives in explaining existing patterns of terror and also provided some
evidence that there may be gains in predicting out-of-sample events as well.

Our analyses mainly focused on single-country samples of domestic terror-
ism, including Afghanistan and Nigeria. Doing so allowed us to assess how the
patterns of attacks in a given country changed over time. In our analysis of
these real-world data, we were also able to consider how the presence of multiple groups may affect the resulting behaviors. For example, analyzing Nigeria between 2009 and 2017, our results considering attacks from Boko Haram and Fulani extremists – the two main groups operating over this period – as separate samples offered substantial gains relative to treating these as a single set of attacks, which is often done in applied research. Moreover, the flexibility of our bivariate spatio-temporal point process model indicated an evolution in the relationship of attacks across these two groups over time (e.g., increasing dispersion in cross-triggering over time).

Statistical modeling of terrorism patterns provides valuable information for
scientists, policymakers, and the general public. The methods developed here
can also be applied to a wide range of additional problems with complex spatio-
temporal patterns, including crime, earthquakes, and diseases. The R code developed for this project is publicly available, enabling researchers to apply these methods. Graduate students have been trained on this project, jointly advised by the two Principal Investigators. Results of this project have been published in peer-reviewed journals in statistics and political science, and additional work is currently under review. Multiple seminars were given at international conferences and universities.
